user_request: A poem for Valentine's Day about true love lasting forever.
final_poem:
## The Long Home

You said it once, somewhere past the kitchen table,
some gray evening when the dog let out its last
expectation and we sat holding our quiet
separate things. I heard you clearly.

You were talking about forever—not the kind
that fills a ring or buys a house or makes a promise,
but the kind that has no word for itself, the one
that stands behind all those other versions

the way a field stands behind a fence. You said it
like someone finding a stone in their pocket,
something carried so long they can't remember
why—but holding it close against the bone.

I believed you then. Not because of any proof.
Because I'd seen you crouch beside a weed
in July, pulling it up from the wall
and not even wincing. Because you didn't

You were standing at the window that day,
Valentine's actually, though neither of us mentioned it—
the yard was silver everything and you were looking down
at something on the sill, some small bird

I'd never named. You named it. Then you said:
*This is what I mean by loving.*

   *What?*

   *Everything that doesn't ask to be loved first.*
   
And you were right. I've watched you open your whole self
to a door that didn't exist, to weather, to the ground.
That's not bravery— that's something older,

the way a river keeps its current without choosing it,
the way dark holds light without refusing.

I want to spend my life proving this to you
not by saying anything but by staying

   here:   in the kitchen,    under the good light,
   not doing anything special except noticing
how your thumb cracks on that glass, how you tilt your head
when you listen. These are the things that will carry us,

these small attendances—  not the grand declaration
but the ordinary devotion to being present

for the ordinary miracles: a knock at the door,
a won dog, the way the body lets you open your mouth
and sound keeps coming out without your asking.

That's what I love. That's what I want to give.
The good kind of answer—  not the one that swells
but the one that still lets you breathe,

that opens its hands wide enough to hold

   nothing, really—just the feeling of holding.

This is forever. This is all it asks for.
